description: From the participle stem of Medieval Latin capitulare (“draw up under headings”), from Latin capitulum (“heading, chapter, title”), diminutive of caput (“head”).

verbs.description: capitulate (third-person singular simple present capitulates, present participle capitulating, simple past and past participle capitulated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To surrender; to end all resistance, to give up; to go along with or comply.
examples: He argued and hollered for so long that I finally capitulated just to make him stop.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To draw up in chapters; to enumerate.
(transitive, obsolete) To draw up the articles of treaty with; to treat, bargain, parley.
examples: there capitulates with the king  […]  to take to wife his daughter Mary
